article.description:
Kyle Korver's shot was way off the first 35
minutes of the game, and he was on the bench the last five.
article.headline: Bluejays rally from 15-point deficit to win in OT
article.linkText: Without Korver, Creighton still defeats SMS in OT
article.story: OMAHA, Neb. (AP) -- Kyle Korver's shot was way off the first 35 minutes of the game, and he was on the bench the last five. Still, 12th-ranked Creighton managed to escape with a 70-67 overtime victory over Southwest Missouri State on Wednesday night. "We did just enough to get by,'' Korver said. Brody Deren's inside basket gave Creighton the lead and then Michael Lindeman made two free throws with 2.3 seconds left as the Bluejays came back from a 15-point deficit. Creighton (22-2, 12-1 Missouri Valley Conference) won its 14th straight home game, despite playing the extra period without Korver. The MVC's leading scorer fouled out in the final minute of regulation after keying the Bluejays' comeback. "I've got to give our players credit,'' Creighton coach Dana Altman said. "Things weren't happening for us tonight, and we still found a way to win. I know Southwest isn't happy to hear that because they played their hearts out.'' Deren's basket gave Creighton a 68-67 lead. The Bears (13-8, 9-3) got the ball with 11 seconds left and had a chance to take the lead. But Terrance McGee missed a shot from inside the lane. "I thought it was a good shot,'' McGee said. "I guess it wasn't meant to be.'' Lindeman rebounded McGee's miss and was fouled with 2.3 seconds left. He made both free throws for the final margin. Korver led the Bluejays with 16 points, and Lindeman added 14. McGee had 19 points and Tamarr Maclin and Merrill Andrews 12 each for the Bears. Maclin also had 12 rebounds. "I love my team,'' Bears coach Barry Hinson said, "and I thought what they did tonight showed a tremendous amount of grit.'' Korver missed eight of his first 10 shots and was held in check most of the game, but scored eight points in the final 5½ minutes of regulation as the Bluejays rallied. "The first half, I couldn't make a thing. I don't know why,'' said Korver, who finished 4-of-12. "They were all just a little bit off. The second half, I got going. I kept on firing them.'' As time was running down on the shot clock, he took a pass from Tyler McKinney, pulled up at the top of the key and drained a 3-pointer that narrowly beat the buzzer and evened the score at 51 with 5:18 left. Korver then gave the Bluejays their first lead of the night, making two free throws for a 53-51 advantage. After McGee's short shot rattled in and out, Korver hit another 3 to put Creighton up by five with 2:41 left. Southwest Missouri wouldn't go away, though. Kellen Easley hit a short shot and Andrew made two free throws to make it a one-point game with 42.5 seconds left. Lindeman made two free throws to push Creighton's lead back to three points. Korver fouled out with 32.1 seconds left, and McGee made both free throws to make it a one-point game again. Trevyor Fisher fouled McKinney, who made one of two free throws with 18.7 seconds left. Maclin hit an inside shot with 4 seconds remaining to tie it at 59. McKinney's long 3-point try hit the front of the rim at the buzzer, forcing overtime. "Going into overtime, I was a little worried because they shut us down the last two minutes of regulation,'' Deren said. "We didn't get the stops we needed, and I was worried they would have the momentum. Luckily, we were able to make plays down the stretch.''
